anime.description: Soon after transferring to http://anidb.net/ch65888 [Seisou Gakuin], http://anidb.net/ch65884 [Kanade] finds the orchestra club in the middle of preparing for the national concourse. Teaming up with the other members, she will improve her skills, meet new rivals and create memories for what will become an unforgettable summer... Source: lacordadoro.wikia.com

tag.name: shoujo
tag.description: In the context of manga and associated media, shoujo, literally meaning "girl", refers to a female audience roughly between the ages of 10 and 18. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: bishounen
tag.description: Young man whose beauty (and sexual appeal) transcends the boundary of gender or sexual orientation.

tag.name: high school
tag.description: A secondary school that usually contains grades 10 through 12 in Japan, or 9 through 12 in America.

tag.name: target audience
tag.description: Anime, like everything else in the modern world, is targeted towards specific audiences, both implicitly by the creators and overtly by the marketing. While categories are associated with specific sex and age groups, this is not a bar on the anime being enjoyed by people who don`t fit into that band; not only do crossover titles exist, but the categories also have a considerable following outside their main demographic, and a person might as well enjoy anime from all categories. Still, does not invalidate the usefulness of marking a title as one of the categories; the same themes will likely be treated differently in anime geared for different audiences. Only one should not jump the gun and assume that a title will be more or less serious or present content in this or that way due to its target audience, or conversely assume the target audience on the content and its presentation alone. As such, the audience categories help form a broad impression of how a title might work with the announced themes, but offer little to no in-depth information about specific content or its treatment. The audience categories originate from manga magazines, which group titles of a same intended audience into a magazine that is advertised as belonging to that category, and so manga-based anime will have the category from their parent work. As for anime based on other works, the audience is often debatable, but comparing information such as time slot to the manga-based anime generally helps figure out the most likely possibility. If the parent material was classified under multiple audiences over time (for example, it was originally shounen, but then as the plot changed and became more mature, it was reclassified as seinen), and the anime adapts parent material time periods covering multiple audiences, we tag all audiences covered by the anime adaptation.

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: fetishes
tag.description: Everything under fetishes (except for Bishounen and Juujin) is strictly only meant for hentai (18 Restricted) and ecchi anime. In case of ecchi, it must be the main element of the show and not when there`s only some of it, for example, there`s some ecchi in Shinseiki Evangelion, but the fact you get to see Asuka`s pantsu doesn`t warrant it the schoolgirl fetish category. So be careful to which ecchi show you add fetishes; it`s fairly straightforward with hentai, though. Overall, this category tree is to satisfy the needs of people with different fetishes, so they can search for what tingles their tangle; hence why this is restricted to hentai and full ecchi shows.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: school dormitory
tag.description: A school dormitory or residence hall is the student living quarters at an elite academy, boarding school, or military school. The main characters may live or work at the dormitory, and it often becomes the backdrop for a reoccurring part of the story.

tag.name: reverse harem
tag.description: Reverse harem, or sometimes also male harem, is the common name for the gender-reversed version of the usual http://anidb.net/t2859 [harem genre]. In a reverse harem, instead of the usual situation with several female characters focused on one male character, the viewer sees several male characters surrounding a single female character. Aside from the swapping of the characters` genders, the trope`s details are mostly the same, with the majority of the changes relating to the differences in behavior between men and women of the characters` age range. The most notable exception is that, due to the most relevant characteristics of the trope`s fan base, reverse harem authors tend to go for http://anidb.net/t1760 [bishounen] looks. Though they are also exceptions to the common harem genre, harems with homosexual relationships are not covered by reverse harem.

tag.name: music
tag.description: Music anime generally revolves around people concerned with music in their everyday lives. In addition they often adhere to certain genre conventions, the emphasis on training and practice in preparation for competitions, characters desire for self improvement, and pursuit of a specific goal. This is not unlike the Sports category.

tag.name: game
tag.description: Based on an interactive (even if minimally so) form of entertainment software, generally available for PCs, consoles or arcade machines.

tag.name: visual novel
tag.description: The two terms are similar yet different, however, the fact that they look and `feel` the same outweighs the technical differences. For clarification, visual novels are considered a sub-genre of adventure games and the term does not cover simulations. While the two genres often share a common visual presentation, dating sims are sometimes considered to be more statistically based than the "choose your own adventure" style of visual novels; basically, the choices you make might change something else than just the story arc (or your next porn pic). Dating sims can involve several technical elements such as a time limit, several statistics such as looks and charm which can be boosted through exercise, or an "attraction meter" which can increase or decrease depending on one`s decisions.

tag.name: romance
tag.description: Romance describes a story that deals with love between two or more characters typically also having an optimistic ending. Romance is also a difficulty encountered when creating a harem.

tag.name: school life
tag.description: Since a large part of the anime audience still takes part in school life or is visiting college, it is only natural to choose a setting the audience can identify with, be it elementary, middle, or high school. For the older viewers a college setting with more mature real-life problems is appropriate. And since clubs take up so much time in the lives of students, these are obviously also important.

tag.name: the arts
tag.description: The arts represent an outlet of human expression, usually influenced by culture, and driven by human creative impulse. Major constituents of the arts include literature – including poetry, novels and short stories, and epics; performing arts – among them music, dance, and theatre; culinary arts such as baking, chocolatiering, and winemaking; media arts like photography and film, and visual arts – including drawing, painting, and sculpting. Some art forms combine a visual element with performance (e.g. film) and the written word (e.g. comics). From prehistoric cave paintings to modern day films, art serves as a vessel for storytelling and conveying mankind`s relationship with its environment. Source: Wiki

tag.name: OP and ED sung by characters
tag.description: OP and/or ED in this anime is sung by the characters and animation shows them singing.

tag.name: classical music
tag.description: Classical music is art music produced or rooted in the traditions of Western music (both liturgical and secular). It encompasses a broad span of time from roughly the 11th century to the present day. Anime tagged have classical music as a central theme.

tag.name: technical aspects
tag.description: It may sometimes be useful to know about technical aspects of a show, such as information about its broadcasting or censorship. Such information can be found here.

episode.title: はじまりのパルティータ
The Opening Partita
episode.summary: One day, prodigy violinist Kohinata Kanade in the second year of high school receives an anonymous letter after a performance. About the same time she is invited by her childhood friend Kisaragi Ritsu, and heads to Yokohama along with Ritsu’s younger brother Kisaragi Kyoya. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 溜息とアヴェ・マリア
Sighs and Ave Maria
episode.summary: Kanade and Kyoya move to Seiso Academy and enter the orchestra club. They are shocked by club-leader Ritsu’s announcement that they are candidates who would represent Seiso Academy in the national contest. But other members are disgruntled, especially the first-year Cello player Mizushima Haruto, because they could not agree to an ensemble made of people whose abilities they know nothing of. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 夏色のアインザッツ
Summery Einsatz
episode.summary: The National Student Music Contest draws near. Club members of the wind-instrument club of Sendai’s Shiseikan High School arrive at Linden Hall. Kanade meets the stern Hozumi, the cheerful and energetic Misushima, and the club-leader Yagisawa. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 実験はメロディ
A Melodic Experiment
episode.summary: Haru’s childhood friend Nanami Sousuke decides to go back to the chamber music club. Kanade and others visit Amane High School with him, where they meet Myoga Leiji, the leader of the chamber music club. It seems as if he knows about Kanade, but Kanade has no recollection of him. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 気高き薔薇のブリランテ
Brillante of the Noble Rose
episode.summary: Kanade and Kyoya overcome their anxieties, and endeavor in practice for the semifinal. The ensemble of four forge ahead to the semifinal under the strict guidance of Ritsu. On the other hand, Jinnan High School stands on the stage full force, having to overcome their previous defeat. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 彷徨いのラプソディ
The Wandering Rhapsody
episode.summary: Seiso Academy won the third stage under the lead of Ritsu`s performance. But because he strained himself, Ritsu`s wrist gets injured; he can no longer continue with the competition. He picks Kyoya to take his place as first violin in the semifinal, but Kyoya becomes anxious and angrily storms out of Linden Hall. Kanade is anxious as well, and desperately tries to understand what Tohgane meant by "flowering." Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 禁断のパッセージ
The Forbidden Passage
episode.summary: Kanade was overwhelmed by Shiseikan High School`s performance, in which they gave their all. She begins the third stage with unsettled feelings, which shows in the way Kanade plays. It`s a crisis for Seiso academy`s ensemble, but Ritsu`s heroic decision to push through guides each member to rise higher. However, Ritsu has a secret he had been keeping from Kanade and Kyoya... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 英雄たちのアイーダ
Aida of Heroes
episode.summary: The National Student Music Contest has begun. And the school to challenge in the third stage is no other than Shiseikan High School. Kanade struggles being second violin in a battle against the members of Shiseikan High School, as they had just become fast friends at Linden Hall. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 青空のグランドフィナーレ
Blue Sky Grand Finale
episode.summary: Kanada and Leiji make it to the auditorium unscathed, barely in time for the final performances. Amane and Nanami perform with sounds they had never before played. Furthermore, Leiji`s sounds, imbued with love and hate, envelop the auditorium with darkness, swallowing up the audience. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 愛憎のエレジー
Elegy of Love and Hate
episode.summary: The much anticipated final draws near. Unexpected events happen to Kanade, however, who seeks to discover her own sounds. Vaguely she begins to recollect memories of why Leiji is so obsessed with her. An incident happened 7 years ago, which changed the course of their fateful relationship. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 記憶のダ・カーポ
Da Capo of Memories
episode.summary: Seiso Academy is competing against Amano High School on the final stage. Ritsu picks Kanade to play first-violin. But Kanade battles her anxiety since she has never played first before, feeling that she is lacking something. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 咆哮のタランテラ
The Roaring Tarantella
episode.summary: Seiso Academy defeated Jinnan High School at the semifinal. At the next semifinal stage, circumstances haunting Myoga impel things to go an unexpected direction. To have revenge for her younger brother Alan who lost his will to play violin after his competition against Myoga, Enjoji Saeka of the famous St. Cecil High School of Kyushu risks playing a particular composition... Source: crunchyroll
